description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 EAC-sekretariatet has ansökt om stöd för ett integrerat regionalt hälsoprogram under 2016-2020.
Programmets syfte är att, på policynivå, hantera svagheter inom medlemländernas hälsosystem. Om EACs medlemsländer gemensamt och effektivt harmoniserar standarder för SRHR-, mödra-, barn-och HIV/AIDS-hälsotjänster kommer detta att stärka det regional samarbetet inom hälsa. Vidare syftar interventionen till att stärka relevant forskning, innovationer, kunskapsspridning, ledarskap, styrning och ansvarsutkrävande inom regionen. EAC förväntar sig att det långsiktiga resultatet av ett fördjupat samarbete inom ovan nämnda områden kommer att vara att snabbare nå målen om att eliminera den mödra- och barnadödlighet som går att förhindra och att på sikt stoppa AIDS-epidemin.
Projektet har en budget på 45 miljoner kronor över 4,25 år och Sida är den enda givaren. Projektet är en del av EAC-sekretariatets mer övergripande hälsostrategi som omfattar även andra givare. Huvuddelen av projektets kostnader omfattas av löner för anställda vid EAC-sekretariatet samt kostnader för de processer som framtagande av EAC-gemensamma policydokument innebär (möteskostnader, resor m.m).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The EAC secretariat has applied for support to the EAC-Sida integrated health program 2016-2020.
The purpose of the program is to, at a policy level, address weaknesses of member states' health systems. If the member states collectively and effectively harmonize standards for SRHR- maternal-, child and HIV/AIDS health services this will in turn strengthen regional cooperation in health. Furthermore, the program seeks to strengthen relevant research, innovation, knowledge management, leadership, governance and accountability within the region. The EAC expects that the long-term outcome of a deeper collaboration in the abovementioned areas will be that the goals of eliminating preventable maternal- and child mortality and eventually ending the AIDS-epidemic can be reached faster.
The project has a budget of 45 million SEK over 4.25 years and Sida is the sole donor. The project part of the EAC-secretariats more overarching health strategy which includes also other donors. The majority of costs are represented by salaries of project staff at the EAC-secretariat and costs related to development of EAC policies (e.g. workshops, travels, consultancy fees)

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative:
Objective 1: To Harmonize and integrate SRHR/RMNCAH and HIV/AIDS Service Packages, Standards and Guidelines in the East African Community
The EAC Secretariat through the EAC Integrated Health Programme (EIHP) facilitated two key activities under objective 1:
1) National consultations of the draft EAC Regional Minimum Package on RMNCAH/HIV Services and the Draft Report on the situation of STIs, prevention, diagnosis and treatment practices in EAC were held in all 6 Partner States. Following on from the national validation meetings, the Partner States developed action plans to ensure timely adoption, implementation and reporting on the key study recommendations, and further requested the EAC Secretariat to develop a regional framework (indicators) for monitoring and reporting on the level of integration.
2) Minimum Standards for RMNCAH and HIV and AIDS integration and linkages for the EAC region were developed (with additional technical support from UNFPA through the 2Gether4SRHR programme). The purpose of the Minimum Standards is to harmonize and standardize delivery of integrated RMNCAH and HIV interventions and services across EAC Partner States. The integration study reports have also been used in the development of national instruments and to develop advocacy materials for RMNCAH and HIV integration.
The 20th Ordinary Meeting (hybrid) of the EAC Sectoral Council of Ministers was conducted on 23rd April 2021 and among other things directed the Partner States to strengthen integration of RMNCAH and HIV and AIDS by adopting and implementing the study recommendations, and to report progress to the 21st Sectoral council for policy guidance (planned for March/April 2022).
2) The EIHP supported all Partner States in the review and finalization of the national reports for the study on the burden of STIs in the region, the Boresha Huduma STI Study. The EIHP facilitated an experts workshop to draft the EAC STI Study Regional report and to develop advocacy materials. In all Partner States, the study findings have been used to inform new national STI strategy documents, and STI programming in general. In Uganda, the study findings have been used to update the national STI guidelines and other STI surveillance tools.
Objective 2: Strengthen SRHR/RMNCAH and HIV&AIDS, TB and STIs Research, Innovations and Knowledge Management in the EAC
Two activities were planned as part of Objective 2, operationalisation of the EAC regional Knowledge Management strategy through the EAC regional Knowledge Management Portal and operationalisation of the EAC regional electronic DHIS2 data warehouse system for housing SRHR/RMNCAH, HIV/AIDS and STIs data and generating the EAC regional scorecards.
1) The EIHP maintained the EAC regional Knowledge Management Portal for health https://health.eac.int during the reporting period and portal content was updated. The EIHP reported that there was increased traffic from EAC Partner States and use (measured by visits and numbers of downloads). The EAC also reported that visitors from the US, UK, India and Germany also downloaded materials while the university of Oslo has begun to use the portal for teaching purposes.
2) The EIHP programme team collected data on all indicators in the integrated EAC Regional scorecards and updated the electronic DHIS2 data warehouse system for housing SRHR/RMNCAH, HIV/AIDS and STIs data. The programme team developed the 5th edition of the Integrated RMNCAH and HIV and AIDS scorecard 2020/ 2021 which was validated and presented for adoption by the 20th meeting of the Ministers Responsible for Health in April 2021.
Objective 3: Strengthen SRHR/RMNCAH and HIV and AIDS Leadership, Governance and Accountability in the EAC
Two main activities were planned for Objective 3:
1) During the reporting period, the programme organized the data collection of the 2nd edition of the EAC regional state of SRHR/RMNCAH (Women Children and Adolescent Health and HIV & AIDS Report 2020) and the EAC Annual integrated EAC Regional SRHR/RMNCAH and HIV and AIDS Scorecard 2020 at Partner States level. A team of experts from the Partner States was identified to draft the report. Although the report was finalised, it will continue as "draft" until it is submitted to the 21st Sectoral Council of Ministers for approval in March/April 2022.
2) Between 29th November and 3rd December 2020 the EAC Secretariat, the East African Legislative Assembly (EALA) and the Eastern Africa National Networks of AIDS and Health Service Organisations (EANNASSO) jointly convened a meeting between the Members of the EALA and key stakeholders during which the re-drafted EAC SRH Bill was presented. The EIHP then held sensitisation sessions for the General Purpose Committee of EALA on the draft Bill. The workshops reviewed the Bill clause by clause in order to build awareness and capacity. On 15th June 2021 the EAC SRH Bill was printed to the East Africa Community Gazette by the Uganda printing and publishing corporation. On 30th June 2021 the Bill was introduced to EALA Assembly for the 1st Reading and then referred to the General Purpose Committee of the EALA 4th Assembly.
Objective 5: Strengthen the capacity of the EAC Secretariat and Partner States to coordinate and implement the project and related global and Africa regional Initiatives
As part of Objective 5, the EIHP focuses on developing human resources and operational capacity of the EAC and Partner States to coordinate and implement SRHR/HIV and AIDS and the project as well as providing coordination and oversight.
1) During the period, the programme convened one meeting of the Joint Technical Working group/RMNCAH and HIV and AIDS managers in October 2020, and four virtual expert meetings with the experts from the Partner States.
2) The EIHP convened two meetings of the Expert Working Group on Sustainable Financing to discuss the resource tracking tool and the harmonized indicator framework for each Partner State. Further, the programme convened a virtual meeting and disseminated the regional resource mobilization strategy, and each country reviewed the national priority action plans for UHHC financing.
3) The programme convened a retreat to draft a second edition of the overarching programme document to guide implementation of the integrated RMNCAH, HIV and AIDS, TB and STI intervention in the region.
4) The review of the EIHP was finalised and approved by the Sectoral Council of Ministers of Health.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
